results.title: All that Bach
results.creator_credit: Larry Weinstein, Louise Clark and Niv Fichman
results.brief_description: All that Bach is a delightful celebration of the music of J S Bach as it is played, danced, sung, jazzed, computed, tapped, electrified and busked by a wide range of internationally renowned artists. Among the performers highlighted in this spectacular homage are jazz pianist Keith Jarratt, Christopher Hogwood and the Academy of Ancient Music, contralto Maureen Forrester, cellist Anner Bylsma, the Canadian Bass and the National Tap Dance Company. “All that Bach” is an entertaining feast that revels in the richness of Bach’s musical legacy.

results.title: All summer in a day
results.creator_credit: Ed Kaplan, Karl Epstein and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: Based on a short story by Ray Bradbury, this short film is set on a planet where the sun shines for only a few minutes once every nine years. Margot, a frail loner, wistfully recalls her days on sunny Earth and waits longingly for the rare appearance of the sun. But she pays dearly for her sensitivity when, as a victim of teasing, she is locked in a closet for the duration of the event. The other children, overwhelmed by the sun’s warmth, have forgotten and left her there. By the time they release her it’s too late - the rain has begun to fall. This is a tale of the destructive nature of thoughtlessness and cruelty.

results.title: All star casting
results.creator_credit: Edward Cook and Big Six Film Unit
results.brief_description: Describes the processes employed in a large British foundry. Begins in the pattern makers shop and then shows making of sand moulds. After pouring, the moulds are allowed to cool and then broken to remove castings. Moulding sand is collected for re-use. Shock blasting is employed to clean castings after which they are machined and annealed. Castings manufactured by the firm include parts for tractors, fork lifting trucks, cranes, excavators and internal combustion engines.

results.creator_credit: Delbert Mann, Norman Rosemont and Marble Arch Productions
results.brief_description: Made for television, this adaptation of Erich Maria Remarque’s passionate anti-war novel is a remake of the 1930’s film classic about young German soldiers in the Great war of 1914-18, and of the veteran who teaches them to grow up fast in the trenches. Stars Richard Thomas, Ernest Borgnine, Patricia Neal, Ian Holm and Donald Pleasence.

results.title: All quiet on the western front
results.brief_description: Regarded as a landmark in American cinema, and a film which pioneered depiction of the “irony” of war. The directional quality has been compared with Eisenstein for its biting commentary and emotional outcry against war. Its bravura direction fixed in millions of viewers minds the image of youth in the trenches. Lead star, Lew Ayres, became a true-to-life conscientious objector of war after portraying its moving scenes.

results.title: All over the shop
results.creator_credit: Peter Pickering, J.D. Chambers, European Productivity Agency and Data Film Productions
results.brief_description: Shows examples of how Work Study has been applied in the reorganization of departments in three different firms. In the packing department of a large pharmaceutical works the flow of work was improved, the individual jobs made easier by the use of simple cheap apparatus made for the purpose. Unnecessary movement of personnel was eliminated in the making-up department of a hosiery firm by adoption of a new layout involving the use of conveyor belts. In the sheet metal shop of an electronic instrument firm, Work Study was used to relieve the shortage of skilled operatives.

results.title: All over me
results.creator_credit: Alex Sichel, Dolly Hall, Baldini Pictures, Slam Pictures and Medusa Pictures
results.brief_description: Fifteen year old Claude (Alison Folland) works part time in a pizza shop, lives with her mother in a small apartment in Hell’s Kitchen and loves to jam with her best friend Ellen (Tara Subcoff). However, Claude’s world is starting to change; Claude realises that she has developed stronger feelings for Ellen. Ellen is spending less time with Claude because she has a new boyfriend, Mark, whose aggression and homophobia alienate Claude. Luke (Pat Briggs), a gay musician, has moved into her apartment block and encourages Claude’s interest in music and the world she lives in. When Claude meets Lucy (Leisha Hailey from The Murmers), her recognition of her homosexuality comes to the fore. However, Claude’s world and the people in it are careering out of control; violence abounds and Claude witnesses Ellen’s increasingly complex relationship with drugs. The Sichel sisters, Alex (director) and Sylvia (writer) have created a rites-of-passage film about coming out and growing up in the unforgiving environment of Hell’s Kitchen. The desultory mood of the film and the subtle performance of Folland as Claude launches a dramatic debut feature for the Sichel sisters. (Awards: Winner, Gay Teddy bear at the 1997 Berlin Film Festival)
